name: The American Labor Movement: From Haymarket to Amazon
description: The definitive history of American workers organizing for power: from the blood of Haymarket through the rise of the AFL-CIO, the post-war compact, the Reagan-era decline, and the new wave of organizing at Starbucks, Amazon, and beyond.

name: Labor Law and Workers' Rights
description: The legal framework governing American workers: from the NLRA to at-will employment, from collective bargaining to individual rights. How US labor law works, why it's weaker than peer nations, and what reform would look like.

name: Public Sector Unions: Teachers, Police, and the State
description: Government workers and their unions: the teachers striking for school funding, police unions blocking accountability, postal workers, firefighters, and the unique politics of public employee organizing.

name: Women's Labor: Paid, Unpaid, and Undervalued
description: The gendered dimensions of work: from the factory floor to the kitchen table. The gender pay gap, care work, domestic labor, maternal penalties, and the ongoing fight for economic equality.

name: Global Labor: Supply Chains, Sweatshops, and Solidarity
description: The international dimensions of work: from Bangladeshi garment factories to Chinese electronics plants to Mexican maquiladoras. Globalization, labor standards, and the challenge of organizing across borders.

name: Wage Theft, Exploitation, and Worker Safety
description: The unsexy side of labor violations: stolen wages, dangerous workplaces, and the enforcement gap. How employers break the law, who suffers most, and why so little is done about it.

name: The Gig Economy and the Future of Work
description: The transformation of employment in the 21st century: Uber drivers, DoorDash deliverers, Amazon warehouse workers, remote employees, and the fundamental question of what 'work' even means anymore.
